fields.name: Pre-heat oven to 180C/160Cfan/gas 4
Place cod steaks in a single layer in a buttered, oven-proof dish.
Season with salt and pepper and sprinkle over the lemon juice. Add a quarter of the olive oil. Cover with buttered foil and bake for 20 minutes.
Heat the remaining oil in a pan and add the onion, garlic and pepper. Fry over a low heat for 15 minutes.
Stir in the tomatoes, season with salt and pepper and the marjoram. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Pour the tomato mixture over the cod and bake for a further 10 minutes.
Serve with sauteed potatoes and broccoli.
Pre-heat the oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5.
Melt the butter with the oil in a pan and add the mushrooms and garlic. Cook over a high heat for 5 minutes.
Remove the mushrooms and garlic with a slotted spoon, retaining the juices. Add to an oven-proof dish large enough to hold the trout in a single layer.
Add the chopped parsley and cover the base of the dish.
Place the trout on top in a single layer.
Pour over the juices, season with salt and pepper, cover with foil and bake for 30 minutes until the trout are cooked through.
Garnish with lemon wedges and serve with buttered new potatoes.
Heat the oil in a pan large enough to hold the cod steaks in a single layer.
Add the carrots and cook for 2 minutes. Add the leeks, stir and cook for 1 minute. Stir in the cider.
Add the carrots and cook for 2 minutes. Add the leeks, stir and cook for 1 minute. Stir in the cider.
Arrange the cod on top, season with salt and pepper and spread the mushrooms over.
Cover and cook gently for 15 minutes until the cod becomes opaque.
Remove the fish and place on a serving dish. Keep hot.
Mix the butter and flour to a smooth paste. Add to the vegetables and cider gradually in small pieces, stirring until absorbed .
Bring to the boil and simmer for 3 minutes, stirring. Check seasoning.
Spoon over the fish and add the chopped parsley.
Serve with sauteed potatoes.
Finely slice mushrooms and place in a deep bowl.
Add the garlic to the bowl with the lemon juice, Tabasco sauce and olive oil. Season.
Mix well and chill in a serving dish for one hour.
Mix the flaked crabmeat with cream. Stir into the mushrooms and garnish with parsley and olives just before serving.
Serve with crusty bread and a green salad.
Grease a shallow flame-proof dish (suitable for the hob) with butter. Halve the garlic and rub around the dish.
Peel and finely chop the shallots. Skin and deseed the tomatoes and finely chop.
Place the fillets in the dish in a single layer and season with salt and pepper.
Add the chopped shallots and top with tomatoes. Pour over the stock and wine. Cover with buttered greaseproof paper.
Bring to a simmer on the hob then lower the heat and poach gently for six or seven minutes until the fish is cooked through but still firm.
Remove fillets, leaving the shallots and tomatoes in the stock, drain and cool.
Bring the stock to the boil and reduce by a quarter. Remove from the heat. Add the cream. Combine butter and flour to a paste and add in small pea-sized pieces. Whisk thoroughly until fully combined.
Melt the butter and beat with the egg yok. Mix into the cream sauce with the tarragon. Check seasoning and leave to cool.
Just before serving, arrange fillets on a large flat dish and sprinkle with lemon juice. Stir a few drops of Tabasco into the cream. Coat the fillets with the sauch and garnish with parsley.
Serve cold with new potatoes and a green salad.
Make two small thin pancakes per person from the batter and put on one side.
Peel the onion and chop finely. Slice the mushrooms.
Melt a little under half the butter in a pan and fry the onions, celery and mushrooms until soft.
Add the tomatoes and season with a little sugar, salt and pepper. Simmer uncovered until it forms a thick puree.
Skin and flake the haddock and add to the puree with a little lemon juice. Check seasoning.
Spoon two tablespoons of the mixture to the e centre of each of the pancakes and fold over to make an envelope.
Place in a shallow flame-proof dish in one layer. Melt remaining butter a spoon over the pancakes. Top with the cheese. Place under a hot grill until brown and bubbling.
Garnish with lemon wedges and sprigs of parsley.
Serve with buttered, minted peas.
Cut each fillet in half and cut each half lengthways into three or four narrow strips.
Coat each strip with seasoneed flour. Beat the egg and stir in the olive oil. Dip each fillet into the egg/oil mixture and roll in the breadcrumbs.
For the tartare sauce, mix together the mayonnaise, cream, parlsey, gherkins, capers and onion and chill.
Heat the vegetable oil in a deep pan. Test by added a crumb of bread - it should sizzle. Using a basket, lower the goujons into the hot oil. Fry for 2 or 3 minutes until golden.
Remove and rain on kitchen roll. Place in a hot serving dish and sprinkle with salt and add lemon wedges.
Serve with the tartare sauce, crusty bread and a green salad.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Peel and slice the potatoes. Add to a pan of salted, boiling water. Cook for 10 minutes until just cooked. Drain.
Remove the skin and any bones from the fish. Cut into 2.5cm chunks.
Melt three quarters of the butter in a saucepan and stir in the flour. Cook the paste for 1 minute.
Gradually stir in the milk, and stirring continuously, bring to the boil. Simmer for 2 minutes until thickened.
Gently add the fish. Season, cover and cook on a low heat for 10 minutes. Stir gently once or twice to prevent the fish sticking.
Remove from the heat and add the prawns, lemon juice and half the parsley. Check seasoning and place in an oven-proof dish.
Mash the potatoes with the remaining butter parsley and the extra milk. Season with pepper.
Stir in half the parmesan. Spread the potato mixture over the fish.
Mix the remaining parmesan with the breadcrumb and sprinkle on top.
Bake for 25 minutes until the top is browned. Serve with buttered peas.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Grease a shallow oven-proof dish with half the butter. Coat each fillet with seasoned flour and place in the dish in a single layer.
Melt the remaining butter in a pan, stir in the flour and cook for a few minutes. Add the milk gradually, stirring constantly to make a white sauce.
Finely chop the onions and add these and the cheese to the sauce. Chop the prawns and add to the sauce. Season with salt and Cayenne pepper. Add the cream.
Pour the sauch over the fish and bake in the centre of the oven for 30 minutes until browned on top.
Serve with rice or new potatoes and wilted spinach.
Heat grill to medium
Place mackerel fillets on baking tray, skin-side up. Drizzle over half the olive oil and season.
Grill for 10 minutes, until just cooked.
Heat remaining oil in a large frying pan. Fry the shallots until softened and golden.
Add the potatoes and turn up the heat.
Toss the potatoes and shallots - they should break down slightly and start to brown.
Add the lemon juice and petit pois. Toss through to cook gently.
Stir in the chopped herbs and lemon zest and season.
Divide between plates.
Top with a mackerel fillet and a dollop of yoghurt.
Wash the mussels in cold water, scrubbing shells. Throw away any with broken or open shells.
Grease the inside of a large saucepan with butter.
Finely chop the onion and add to the pan with the white wine.
Add the mussels, cover with a lid. Place over a high heat, shaking the pan for 3 to 5 minutes until all the mussels have opened.
Remove the mussels - throw away any that haven't opened.
Take off the empty half shell from each mussel and put the other halves with the mussels in tact into soup plates. Keep hot.
Cream the butter and flour together and mix into the remaining liquid in the pan.
Stir over a low heat until boiling and the sauce has thickened.
Add the chopped parsley and pour over the mussels. Serve immediately.
Serve with French fries.
Pre-heat the oven to 190C/170C/gas 5.
Quarter each piece of chicken, then season with sea salt and black pepper and dust with flour.

Heat a splash of oil in a large, deep pan on a medium heat and fry the chicken until golden brown all over, then transfer to a baking tray and place in the oven for 20 minutes, or until cooked through.
Put the pan back on the heat, add the sliced chorizo and pancetta or bacon and fry until browned and crispy. Add the onion, garlic and parsley stalks, then cook until soft.
Gently heat the chicken stock and infuse half with the saffron.
Add the smoked paprika, the rice and infused stock to the pan and leave to cook on a medium heat for around 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the remaining saffron, peas, prawns, and the mussels to the rice. Place a lid on the pan and cook for a 10 further minutes. Discard any mussels that aren't open.
Add the cooked chicken, sprinkle over the chopped parsley and serve with wedges of lemon for squeezing over.
Mix the cornflour with the soy sauce, sherry and water.
Heat both oils in a large frying pan or wok. Add the ginger, garlic and spring onions and fry for 3 minutes.
Add the mange-tout and fry for a further 3 minutes.
Pour in the cornflour mix and cook over a medium heat until the sauce boils and thickens.
Reduce the heat, add the prawns and simmer for 2 to 3 minutes.
Garnish with the extra prawns.
Serve with egg noodles or plain rice.
Pre-eat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Arrange the fennel slices in a shallow roasting tin or dish (large enough to hold the fish).
Drizzle with quarter of the olive oil and season. Roast for 15 minutes, until starting to soften.
Slash one side of each fish 3 times with a sharp knife. Tuck a bay leaf into each slash.
Remove the fennel from the oven and scatter the chunks of sourdough over.
Place the fish on top, slashed-side up.
Drizzle the fish with half of the olive oil, the vermouth and then season.
Return to the oven and roast for a further 20 minutes or so until the flesh is opaque and comes away easily from the bones.
Mix the reserved fennel fronds, parsley and dill with the sliced olives, remaining olive oil and lemon juice.
Spoon the herb/olive mix over the fish and serve with remaining sourdough bread.
Hard boil the eggs then cover in cold water for 15 minutes. Shell and quarter.
Trim the French beans and cook until tender but still firm in boiling salted water.
Skin and quarter the tomatoes.
Peel and thinly slice the onions and push into separate rings.
Core and deseed the pepper and slice thinly.
Shred the lettuce, and with the beans, toss in half the French dressing .
Drain and flake the tuna. Arrange tuna, drained anchovies, olives, green pepper and onion on top of the lettuce and beans.
Add the eggs and tomatoes and pour over the remaining dressing.
Pre-heat the oven to 190C/170C fan/gas 5.
Place the water, wine, parsley, thyme and bay leaf in a small pan. Season and heat gently until just boiling. Remove from heat and allow to cool until warm.
Butter an oven-proof dish large enough to hold the salmon steaks in one layer.
Add the salmon steaks and pour over the wine and herb mixture. Cover the dish with foil.
Place in the oven for 20 minutes until the salmon is just cooked.
Transfer the steaks to a warmed serving dish.
Strain the wine and herb mixture into a large pan. Boil vigorously until reduced by half.
Remove from the heat and stir a little of the liquid into the fromage frais then add it all to the pan. Check the seasoning.
Warm the sauce for a few seconds - gently to avoid curdling. Stir in the chives and pour over the salmon. Garnish with lemon wedges.
Serve with buttered asparagus and new potatoes.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C. Use a little of the butter to grease a shallow, ovenproof dish.
Peel the potatoes and cut into thin slices.
Peel and finely chop the onion.
Grate the cheese.
Layer potatoes, onion, and cheese seasoning each layer with salt and pepper, finishing with a layer of cheese. Dot with remaining butter.
For a main meal, add flaked cooked fish between the potato layers.
Beat the egg into the milk and pour over.
Cover with foil and bake for 90 minutes until the potatoes are cooked through and the top is golden.
Preheat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4
Place the fillets in one layer in a shallow ovenproof dish.
Pour over the fish stock. Cover with a piece of buttered foil and bake for 20 minutes.
Remove the fillets and place in a hot flame-proof dish. Reserve the cooking liquid.

Melt the butter in a pan, add the flour and cook for 2 minutes. Gradually add the milk, stirring continuously, until the sauce comes to the boil. Reduce to a simmer and cook for 2 minutes, stirring continuously. Season and remove from the heat.
Lightly beat the egg yolk with the cream, blend in a little of the hot sauce, then stir the mixture into the sauce. Pour over the fish.
Sprinkle over the cheese. Put under a hot grill for 5 to 10 minutes until brown and bubbling.
Serve with buttered new potatoes and broccoli spears.

Place the rice in a saucepan and pour in the water. Add salt and pepper and bring to the boil. Stir once, cover the pan and simmer gently for 20 minutes. Leave to stand for 10 minutes without removing the lid.
Put the rice in a bowl and mix in the Parmesan, eggs and a little salt and pepper. Add to the rice, mix thoroughly and set aside until cold.
Take a tablespoon of the cold rice and mould it with a hollow in the centre. Add a cube of mozzarella and cube of meat. Top with a little more rice and shape into a ball about 5cm wide.
Use the rest of mixture to make 3 balls per person, the coat thickly with breadcrumbs.
Heat the oil until a cube of day-old bread browns in 1 minute. Fry the rice balls, 2 or 3 at a time, until golden. Drain on kitchen paper and keep hot.
Garnish with a herb leaf and serve with home-made tomato sauce and a green salad.
Flatten the steak and cut into narrow strips.
Peel and finely chop the onion and slice the mushrooms.
Heat 25g of butter and fry the onion and mushrooms slowly until soft.
Stir in the mustard and enough flour to absorb the fat. Continue frying gently for 2 or 3 minutes.
Blend in the soured cream.
In a clean pan, add the remaining butter and fry the meat on a high heat until brown all over.
Add to the sauce. Season with salt and pepper and lemon juice.
Serve with rice and peas or green beans.
Pre-heat oven to 180C/fan160C/gas 4
To make the pesto, put the garlic, pine nuts, mint, Parmesan, lemon juice and olive oil into a food processor.
Add a pinch of sea salt and pulse until well mixed but still textured.
Lay out the leg of lamb, inside up on a chopping board.
Spread pesto all over inside of lamb.
Roll up and tie with string to secure.
Put the lamb in the roasting tin and make incisions all over (one per anchovy piece).
Insert a piece of anchovy into each incision.
Drizzle the olive oil over the lamb and season with black pepper.
Roast for approximately 1.5 hours.
Rest for 15 minutes
Serve with minted new potatoes and spring greens.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6
Drain the soaked beans and cover with fresh water. Boil rapidly for 10 minutes.
Drain and place in a deep oven-proof dish with the belly pork on top.
Add all the ingredients except the remaining meat.
Cover with cold water, cover with lid and place in the oven for 15 minutes.
Lower heat to 180C and cook for a further 2 hours. After 1 hour, check there is sufficient water to just cover the meat.
Lower heat to 150C and cook for a further 3 hours. Check water level frequently and top up if required.
Add the chicken and cook for a further 90 minutes.
Add the chopped sausage or chipolatas. Lift the belly pork to the surface just above the level of the liquid. Cook for 1 hour with the lid off until the pork is browned.
Serve with crisp French bread.
Heat a splash of oil in a large, deep frying pan with a tight-fitting lid and fry the lamb, in batches, over a high heat until browned. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside on a plate.
In the same pan, fry the aubergine in batches, adding a little more oil if needed, until golden and just cooked through. Remove with a slotted spoon and set aside on another plate.
Reduce the heat and cook the onion until softened (about 10 minutes). Stir in the figs, garlic and spices, then cook for 2 minutes until fragrant.

Return the lamb to the pan, stirring to coat well in the spices, then pour over the hot stock. Bring to a boil over a high heat, then reduce the heat and simmer, covered, for 1.5 hours or until the lamb is very tender.
For the last 10 minutes of so of the cooking time, stir in most of the aubergines and half of the olives, leaving off the lid so the sauce has a chance to thicken.
Season the stew with a little salt and black pepper (the houmous and olives will add a saltiness).
For the houmous, in a food processor or mini chopper, pulse together the chickpeas, garlic, tahini and lemon juice until smooth.
With the processor running, pour in the olive oil in a steady stream along with the ice-cold water until the houmous is very smooth. Season with salt, freshly ground black pepper and more lemon.

Spread the houmous over the base of a large serving dish and spoon over the hot lamb and aubergine stew, top with the remaining aubergine and olives, then scatter over the almonds, herbs and pomegranate seeds. Serve the stew with flatbreads for scooping.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Peel and finely chop the onions. Fry gently in a little of the oil covered with a lid for 5 minutes.
Add the minced beef and fry until well browned.
Add the salt, tomato puree and stock. Season with pepper. Bring to the boil and simmer, covered, for 30 minutes.
Slice the aubergines and fry till golden. Drain on a piece of kitchen roll. Butter an oven-proof dish and add a layer of aubergines.
Cover with a layer of meat sauce, then another layer of aubergines continuing until both are used up, finishing with a layer of aubergines.

Melt the butter in a saucepan, stir in the flour and cook over a low heat for 1 or 2 minutes. Slowly blend in the milk, stirring continuously. Bring to the boil, season with salt and pepper and simmer for 1 to 2 minutes.
Take off the heat and beat in the egg. Spoon over the moussaka.
Place in the centre of the oven for 35 minutes until bubbling and browned.
Serve with a tomato and onion salad and crusty bread.
Tim skin or fat from the pork and cut into 5cm slices.
Place between 2 sheets of greaseproof paper and beat the slices flat with a rolling pin. Place in a flat dish.
Pour the oil and lemon juice into a bowl and season with pepper. Mix in the garlic. Spoon over the pork and leave for 30 minutes.
Melt the butter in a frying pan and add the onion. Fry for 5 minutes or until the onion is soft.
Add the mushrooms and fry for a further few minutes until cooked. Remove the onions and mushrooms and keep hot.
Drain the pork from the marinade and fry in the butter for 3 to 4 minutes, turning once.
Transfer the pork to a hot serving dish and keep warm.
Add the sherry to the pan and heat briskly, stirring continuously, until reduced by half.
Return the onions and mushrooms to the pan and season. Stir in the cream. Heat gently until heated through.
Pour over the pork. Serve with rice or pasta.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Bring a large pan of slightly salted water to the boil. Add the kale and the gnocchi. Cook for 30 seconds then drain and rinse both under cold water.
Heat a little oil in a large frying pan and crumble in the sausage meat. Add the onions and fry for 7 minutes until soft.
Add a handful of basil leaves and the passata and simmer for 3 minutes.
Toss the kale and gnocchi through the sausage mixture then transfer to an oven-proof dish. Tear the cheese and sprinkle over. Season. Bake for 15 minutes until golden and bubbling.
Serve with crusty bread and salad.
Put beans and a sprinkling of thyme in slow cooker.
Heat the oil in a pan and cook the sausages until browned all over.
Place in the slow cooker.
Add the onion and celery to the pan and cook for 5 minutes until softened but not coloured.
Add the wine, rosemary and bay leaf and bring to the boil.
Pour into the slow cooker and season.
Switch slow cooker to high and cook for 5 to 6 hours.
Stir in the chopped tomatoes and cabbage
Cook for a further 30 to 45 minutes.
Serve with ciabatta.
Heat oil in a frying pan over a medium-high heat.
Add the onion and cook until softened - approximately 7 minutes.
Add the garlic and cook for a further minute, before transferring to the slow cooker.
Add a little more oil to the pan and increase the heat to high.
Add the beef and brown, breaking it up as you go. You may need to do this in batches
Transfer to the slow cooker.
Turn the heat to medium and add the red wine. Bring to a simmer, scraping off all the brown bits from the bottom of the pan.
Pour into slow cooker.
Add remaining ingredients and cook on low for 6 hours.
Serve with spaghetti and optional garlic bread.
Heat the oil and a knob of butter in a pan over a low heat. Add the onion and fry gently for 5 minutes.
Increase the heat to medium, add the rice and cook for a few minutes. Add the wine and stir until absorbed.
Gradually add the stock, stirring and allowing each addition to absorb before adding the next.
Blanch the asparagus in a pan of boiling water until just tender, refresh under cold water, then slice into 3cm lengths.
When almost cooked, add the asparagus, lemon zest and juice and cheese. Season, remove from the heat. Cover for 5 minutes before serving.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Pour the milk into a pan and add the onion, bay leaf and season with salt and pepper. Heat until the milk is about to boil, stirring occasionally.
Partially cover, and cook on a low simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the asparagus and return to a gentle simmer for 10 to 12 minutes until just tender.
Rub the flour into the butter and stir in the Parmesan. Add enough water to bind into clumps.
Press together and roll out to fit a flan dish or individual tins. Prick the pastry base with a fork. Chill for 15 minutes.
Line with baking parchment and add baking beans.
Bake for 15 minutes. Take out of the oven and remove the paper and beans. Turn the oven down to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Strain the asparagus tips and onion, retaining the milk and discarding the bay leaves.
Spoon the asparagus and onion into the flan dish.
Beat the eggs and yolk with the chives, then gradually add the reserved milk.
Pour into the pastry case. Bake for 45 minutes until set and browned on top.
Serve hot or cold with buttered new potatoes and a cherry tomato salad.
Heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7.
Heat the olive oil in a large frying pan, then gently fry the onion for 5 minutes.

Blanch the broccoli in salted boiling water for 3 minutes. Drain well, add to the pan, then turn up the heat and fry for 3 to 4 minutes, stirring, until slightly coloured. Stir in a grating of Parmesan and season well.
Divide the vegetable mixture among 1 ramekin per person. Crack 2 eggs into each ramekin and season. Divide the cream between the ramekins, then grate over more parmesan.
Put the ramekins on a baking tray and bake for 6 to 8 minutes until the whites are cooked.
Serve the baked broccoli and parmesan eggs with slices of garlic butter toast.
Pre-heat the oven to 180°C/160°C fan/gas 4.
For the béchamel sauce, put a large saucepan over a medium heat, add the butter and flour, then gently heat while stirring to form a paste. Gradually add the milk, stirring continuously.
Add the bay leaf and clove, then continue to stir until the sauce is thick, smooth and just coming to the boil. Add a little freshly grated nutmeg and season with salt and white pepper to taste.
In a separate pan over a medium heat, gently cook the shallot in some butter until soft – about 10 minutes. Add the peas and broad beans (blanched if using fresh), stir and season.

Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil. Add the pasta and cook for a couple of minutes less than stated on the pack instructions. Strain the pasta and put it straight into the béchamel sauce while still hot.

Add the chopped herbs, spinach, vegetable mixture, most of the Grana Padano, half the Mozzarella and a grating of nutmeg. Gently mix everything together, stirring in a little extra milk to loosen if necessary.

Lift the pasta from the pan with tongs, divide evenly among ramekins or gratin dishes (1 per person) and spoon over any sauce left in the pan. Top with the remaining Grana Padano, mozzarella and a drizzle of melted butter.
Bake for 20 minutes until golden and bubbling on top.
To serve, sprinkle with the toasted breadcrumbs and spoon over a little fresh pesto.
Serve with salad and crusty bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 190C/17C fan/gas 5.
Cook the onion, carrot, garlic and celery in half the oil for 10 minutes, stirring frequently.
Drain the soya beans and mash, or use a food processor to produce a coarse paste.
Combine the onion mixture, soya beans, parsley, oregano, mace and breadcrumbs. Season well.
Add enough of the beaten egg to bind the ingredients. Shape into round patties - two per person.
Grease a baking sheet with a little oil and place the patties on it, brush with a little oil.
Bake for 30 to 40 minutes until well browned.
Serve with a tomato chutney and salad.
Heat the butter and oil in a large saucepan. Add the pine nuts and cook until lightly browned.
Stir in the spring onions and leave on a low heat.
Bring a large pan of boiling, salted water to the boil. Add the broccoli and cook for 5 minutes until just tender.
Remove the broccoli with a slotted spoon and add to the spring onions.
Bring the water back to the boil, topping up if necessary. Add the pasta and reduce the heat. Cook for about 3 minutes until tender.
Drain well. Stir the broccoli and spring onion mixture. Add the past and toss, then turn it into a warmed serving dish. Top with the cheese.
Serve with crusty bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Cook the cauliflower in boiling, salted water for 5 minutes. Drain
Melt the butter in a large saucepan and add the leeks, garlic, marjoram and bay leaf. Cook for 10 minutes, stirring frequently, until softened.
Stir in the tomato paste, tinned tomatoes and season. Heat until simmering and cook gently for 10 minutes.
Cut the cauliflower in florets and dice the stalk. Stir the cauliflower and parsley into the leek mixture. Remove from the heat.
Add both cheeses to the hot white sauce.
Layer the leek mixture and the pasta in a baking dish, finishing with a layer of pasta.
Pour over the cheese sauce. Bake for 40 minutes.
Serve with crusty bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4.
Lightly butter a large oven-proof dish. Layer the sliced potatoes and celeriac randomly in the dish.
Put the remaining ingredients in a large pan, bring just to the boil, then season. Pour into the dish, cover with foil and bake for 40 minutes. Check halfway through, and pat down with a spatula.
Uncover and bake for a further 10-15 minutes, until golden. Stand for 10 minutes before serving.
Preheat the oven to 180C/fan 160C/gas 4.

Grease an oven-proof dish with the butter, then cover the base with half the potato slices arranged in 2 layers. Top with half the sliced beetroot, all the sliced celeriac, then the remaining beetroot, seasoning lightly between each layer.
Finish with two layers of the remaining potato slices.

Mix the cream, mustard, nutmeg and Gruyère together in a jug, then pour over the layered vegetables. Bake for 1 hour 30 minutes until the top is golden and the vegetables are tender when pierced with a knife.
To make an accompanying salad, whisk together the honey, mustard and vinegars in a large bowl. Season well, then whisk in the oil. Whisk in the lemon juice to taste.
Pour half the dressing out of the bowl into a jug. Just before serving, add the salad to the bowl and toss well, then add more dressing to taste.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/ 180C fan/gas 6.
Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil over a high heat. Add the macaroni and cook for 8 minutes or until it still has some bite (al dente).
For the last 2 minutes, add the broccoli, then drain and rinse under cold water to refresh. Cover with damp kitchen paper.

In another large saucepan, warm the olive oil over a medium heat. Add the onion and gently fry for 10 minutes or until soft. Add the flour, turn up the heat slightly and cook for 2-3 minutes, stirring.

Turn the heat to low, then slowly add the milk, whisking all the time. Turn the heat to medium and stir until the mix thickens and boils gently. Add the spinach and half the grated cheeses. Stir until the spinach wilts and the cheese melts.

Add the pasta and broccoli, season to taste, then pour into an oven-proof dish. Mix the rest of the cheese with the breadcrumbs, then use to top the macaroni. Bake for 20-25 minutes until the top is golden brown and bubbling.
Serve with a green salad.
Heat the oven to 120C/100C fan/gas 2

Mix the polenta with a little salt and white pepper. Carefully turn the tub of ricotta out onto a baking tray lined with baking paper, then spoon the polenta over the ricotta to roughly coat it – this helps the ricotta dry out in the oven.
Bake for 2.5 hours until it starts to dry out and firm up. Take out of the oven and leave to cool
Break off the tough ends of the asparagus, and break each one into three pieces. Put the prepared spears in iced water and set aside.

Put the trimmings in a pan with the water and some salt, bring to the boil and simmer for 30 minutes to make a stock. When the stock is ready, pass it through a sieve (discard the solids), return the stock to the pan and bring it back to the boil.
Blanch the iced asparagus spears in the stock for about 30 seconds, then return them to the iced water. Keep the stock to one side

Put a good splash of olive oil in a large frying pan set over a medium-high heat. Break the eggs into the hot pan and quickly add the blanched asparagus spears, tomatoes, olives, chives, salt and pepper, then the cheese.

When the egg whites are half-set, break the yolks with a wooden spoon and briefly mix together. Remove from the heat and briefly stir again - the whites and yolks should remain mostly separate. Add a splash of asparagus stock if the mixture is too dry.

Put 2 toast halves per person on warmed serving plates. Top with the eggs and a dollop or two of baked ricotta, then scatter over the pea shoots, toasted chopped hazelnuts and a little extra grated cheese.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6.
Put the cherry tomatoes on a baking tray, drizzle with a little oil and season. Roast for 20 minutes until softened.
Cut the pastry into 1 rectangle per person and transfer to a baking sheet. Lightly score a border 1cm from the edge of each rectangle and prick the middles with a fork.
Bake for 8 minutes until puffed up and just starting to turn golden. Press the centres of the rectangles down with your fingers, leaving the border raised higher.
In a small bowl mix the cream cheese, half the egg yolk, Parmesan and chives, season and divide among the tarts. Top with the tomatoes. Brush over the pastry borders with the remaining egg yolk.
Bake for 10 to 12 minutes until the pastry is puffed and golden. Drizzle with oil and scattered with fresh basil leaves.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Line and grease and Swiss roll tin.
Fry half the onion in the large knob of the butter for 10 minutes.
Cook the broccoli in boiling, salted water for 10 minutes. Drain and chop finely.
Stir the broccoli into the onion and mix in the ricotta. Season and set aside.

Melt the half the remaining butter and cook the rest of the onion for 5 minutes. Stir in the flour then gradually add the milk until combined. Remove from the heat without bringing it to the boil or thickening the sauce.
Place the chestnut puree in a bowl and break into pieces. Beat until smooth.
Beat in the egg yolks and Parmesan cheese and season with the ground mace, cloves and cinnamon. Gradually mix in the sauce.
Whisk the egg whites until stiff. Stir the breadcrumbs into the sauce . When incorporated, stir in a quarter of the egg whites. Stir in the rest of egg whites with a metal spoon.
Turn the mixture into the tin and spread evenly. Bake for about 20 minutes until it is risen, set and browned.
Lay a tea towel on the work surface and cover it with a piece of foil, shiny side underneath.
Melt the remaining butter and brush it over the foil. Turn the roulade on to the foil. Remove the paper and trim any crisp edges.
Make a shallow slit across one long end about 1cm from the edge.
Spread the filling over the roulade then roll it up using the foil and tea towel as a guide.
Pinch the foil loosely at the ends of the roll. Place on a baking sheet and bake for 10 minutes to set.
Serve sliced with a hot, home-made tomato sauce and red cabbage.
Fry the onion and bacon until cooked and the onion is soft. Remove from the pan with a slotted spoon.
Combine potato, cabbage, onion and bacon. Shape into patties about 1cm thick.
Fry until golden brown.
Serve with a fried egg or as a vegetable course.
Put the potatoes in a large pan with just enough water to cover them and crumble in the stock cubes. Bring to the boil, then cover and cook for 5 mins
Add the courgettes, put the lid back on and cook for 5 mins more. Throw in the spring onions, cover and cook for a final 5 mins.
Take off the heat, then stir in the cheese and season with grated nutmeg, salt and pepper. Liquidise to a thick soup, adding more hot water until at the right consistency.
Serve scattered with extra grated cheddar, spring onions and grated nutmeg or pepper.
Serve with crusty bread.
Gently heat half olive oil in a large frying pan. Fry the onion for 5 minutes until softened but not brown.
Heat the stock in a large pan. Add the rice to the onions, then stir for a minute so the grains are coated in butter and slightly translucent.
Add the wine and increase the heat to medium-high. Stir until the wine has evaporated, then add a ladleful of the hot stock. Stir until the stock has been absorbed, then add another ladleful.
Keep adding stock and stirring until the rice is creamy and cooked but with some bite (it will take about 20 minutes and you may not need all the stock).
In another pan, gently fry the leeks in the remaining olive oil and a knob of butter with the thyme leaves until soft. Stir the leeks into the rice just before the end of cooking.
Season, then crumble in the gorgonzola or vegetarian equivalent. Cover, take off the heat, leave for 2-3 minutes, then serve.
Pre-heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7.

Boil the potatoes in a large pan of water for 12-15 minutes until tender. Drain well, then tip into a medium ovenproof dish, gently squashing them with the back of a spoon. Drizzle with olive oil, season well, then bake for 20-30 minutes until crispy.
Heat a frying pan, then add the olive oil and fry the onion, garlic and ginger with some salt for 8 minutes over a low to medium heat until softened, stirring occasionally.

Stir in the chilli flakes and tomatoes, adding water to make a sauce if necessary. Stir in the sun-dried tomatoes, dried and fresh herbs and pomegranate molasses, then simmer over a low heat for 10 minutes.
Add more salt and pepper to taste (halloumi is already salty).

Once the potatoes are crispy, turn the grill to medium-high. Spoon the tomato sauce over the potatoes, then arrange the halloumi on top. Brush with oil, then grill for 5-6 minutes until the halloumi is golden.
Top with the yogurt, spring onion, basil and a drizzle of pomegranate molasses.
Serve with crusty bread.
Preheat oven to 180C/fan160C/gas 4
Heat the oil in a pan over a medium heat.
Add the onion and cook until soft, approximately 3 minutes.
Add the garlic, smoked paprika and cumin, cook for another minute.
Add the beans and passata and bring to the boil.
Turn the heat to low and mash the beans with a potato masher.
Simmer for 5 minutes.
Remove the mixture from the heat and strain, reserving the sauce.
Transfer the bean mixture to a bowl and mix with half the cheese, the coriander, red pepper and red onion.
Spread half the sauce in the bottom of a baking dish.
Divide the bean mixture between the tortillas and roll tightly.
Place rolled tortillas in the baking dish and cover with remaining sauce and sprinkle with remaining cheese.
Cover and bake for 25 minutes.
Remove cover and bake for a further 5 minutes.

Put the chickpea flour in a large mixing bowl with a generous pinch of sea salt and gradually whisk in the water to form a smooth, thin batter. Cover with cling film and leave to rest at room temperature overnight
Heat the oven to 240C/220C fan/gas 9
Skim off any froth from the surface of the farinata batter and whisk in just under a third of the olive oil.

Divide the remaining oil between oven-proof frying pans (2 pans measuring 24 to 26cm for 8 people) . Heat over a high heat until almost smoking, then pour a little of the mixture into each pan and swirl quickly to coat the bases until bubbling.

Divide the remaining batter between the pans, pouring it on top of the bubbling batter to a depth of around 2cm, then transfer to the oven and bake for 10 to 12 minutes until golden on top. The pancakes should still be a little wobbly in the very centre.
Heat the extra oil and half the butter equivalent in a frying pan over a medium heat. Add the mushrooms and gently fry until soft.
Add the rest of the butter and the sage leaves, turn up the heat and cook until the butter is just browned and the sage is crisp.
Remove the farinata from the oven and divide the mushrooms between the pans. Serve in the pans at the table, to be sliced and shared.
Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Place each potato on a wooden spoon and make vertical slices, not quite all the way through and 0.25cm apart. Arrange the potatoes in the casserole and brush all over with half of the melted butter.

Slot the bay leaves between gaps in the potatoes, poke in the garlic bulb halves and season well with sea salt and black pepper. Bake for 1 hour until tender and golden brown, brushing again with the melted butter halfway through.
Put the sliced onion in a glass or ceramic bowl with the vinegar, sugar and a couple of pinches of salt. Set aside.
Remove the casserole from the oven. Scatter over half the grated cheese, drizzle over half the cream and wine, then top with half the onion.
Splash some kirsch over. Repeat the layers with the rest of the cheese, cream, wine and onion, and add another splash of kirsch.
Cover the casserole with the lid and return to the oven for 10-15 minutes until the cheese is melted and oozing, then remove the lid and cook for 10-15 minutes more to reduce the wine.
Serve with the cornichons and a salad of peppery green salad leaves, such as rocket and chicory, dressed in a classic vinaigrette.
Heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.

Make a tomato sauce by heating the olive oil in a saucepan with a lid. Add the onion and cook until softened. Stir in the tomatoes, season with salt and black pepper, then cover the pan with the lid and simmer gently for 25 minutes.

Dust the aubergine slices in the flour, then dip into the beaten egg. Pour 1cm oil into a large frying pan over a medium-high heat. Fry the aubergine slices for 2 to 3 minutes on each side until golden. Remove and drain on kitchen paper.

Line up the aubergine slices on a large chopping board, season with salt and pepper, then sprinkle with half of the parmesan. Divide the basil leaves and place on each aubergine slice and top with half the mozzarella.
Carefully roll up each slice, then place them seam-side down on the board.
Line a large oven-proof dish with about a quarter of the tomato sauce and put the aubergine rolls on top, seam-side down – leave a couple of centimetres around each roll.
Spoon the rest of the tomato sauce over and around, then top with the remaining mozzarella slices and parmesan.
Bake for 15-20 minutes until the top is golden brown and beginning to bubble. Serve with extra basil leaves and a side salad.
Serve with the extra basil leaves and a side salad.
Preheat oven to 230C/fan 210C/gas 8
Soak the gnocchi in boiled water for a few minutes.
Add to a baking tray along with pepper, tomatoes and garlic.
Drizzle with the olive oil and sprinkle over rosemary. Season.
Bake for around 25 minutes, tossing halfway through.
Sprinkle over some vegan grated cheese and return to oven for another 5 minutes.
Heat the oil in a large saucepan and fry the onion over a medium heat for 5 minutes or until it starts to soften.

Add the flour and fry for a minute more before gradually whisking in the milk. Bring to a simmer, stirring continuously until the sauce thickens and bubbles, then reduce the heat and stir in the cream cheese. Turn off the heat.
Put the kale in a colander and pour over a kettle of boiling water. Drain, refresh with cold water, then squeeze out as much water as possible.
Heat the grill to medium-high. Boil a large saucepan of water. Add the gnocchi and broccoli to the boiling water and simmer for 4 to 5 minutes, then drain and pat dry.
Stir the veg and gnocchi into the sauce, then pour into a baking dish. Sprinkle over the grated cheese and grill for 15 minutes or until golden.
Serve with a mixed salad.
Rinse and shake the spinach and cook without adding more water until wilted. Drain and press out any moisture. Chop.
Place the spinach in a bowl and mix in the ricotta cheese and eggs. Stir in the flour and half the Parmesan. Season with salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Turn the gnocchi mixture into a flat dish, smooth the surgace and chill for 2 hours until firm.
Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil then to a gentle simmer. Shape the gnocchi mixture into small balls, 1.5cm wide in floured hands. Drop into the water a few at at a time.
Remove when they have puffed up and risen to the surface with a slotted spoon.
Arrange the gnocchi in a buttered flame-proof dish, melt the butter and pour over. Sprinkle over the remaining Parmesan.
Place under a hot grill until browned. Serve with a rocket salad.
Prepare the chickpeas according to the instructions on the packet. (This usually involves soaking overnight and then boiling for an hour.)
Place half the puff pastry on a baking tray, keeping it on the baking parchment that comes with it.
Spread the hummus over it and drizzle with the pesto (you may need to loosen it with a little olive oil).
Scatter the chickpeas, spring onion and cherry tomatoes over the top.
Cover with the spinach leaves and a generous amount of vegan grated cheese.
Cover with the remaining puff pastry, and crimp the edges to form a parcel.
Bake in the oven according to the instructions on the puff pastry packet.

Peel the potatoes, cutting any large ones in half. Put in a pan of lightly salted water and bring to the boil. Simmer for 15 minutes or until completely tender, then drain and return to a low heat to steam dry.
Grate the Cheddar into the potato with a good knob of butter and 2 heaped tsp English mustard, then pass through a ricer or push through a metal sieve with the back of a spoon.
Season generously. Stir through the spring onions. When the mash has cooled slightly, shape into 8 small cakes, then dust lightly in the seasoned plain flour.
When the mash has cooled slightly, shape into small cakes - 2 per person, then dust lightly in the seasoned plain flour.

Heat a splash of olive oil in a pan and fry the cakes for 5 minutes on each side or until golden and crisp, though soft in the centre, flipping over carefully. Fry in batches with extra oil if necessary.
Serve with chopped walnuts and crisp salad leaves.
Preheat the oven to 200C/fan180C/gas 6.
Melt the butter in a large pan over a medium heat. Add the onion, celery and garlic, season, then cover with a lid and cook gently for 10 to 15 minutes until softened.
Drain the porcini, then roughly chop. Add all the mushrooms to the softened onion mixture with the sage and chestnuts and fry for 5 minutes. Stir in the flour and cook for 2 minutes.
Add the milk, little by little, stirring, until the mixture thickens. Season, then leave to cool.

Half-fill a large pan with water and bring to the boil. Add the kale and simmer for 3 minutes or until tender. Drain and refresh under cold water, then squeeze out the liquid and pat dry in a clean tea towel.
Add to the mushroom mix, check the seasoning, then pour everything into an oven-proof dish.
Roll out the pastry on a lightly floured surface to the thickness of a £1 coin. Trim so it’s a little bigger than the dish. Brush the rim of the dish with a little plant-based milk.
Cut the pastry trimmings into strips, lay over the rim, then brush with a little more milk. Lay the rolled-out pastry over the top and press the edges to seal.
Cut shapes from any leftover pastry to decorate. Brush the pie with the remaining beaten egg, then bake for 25 minutes until crisp and golden.
Serve with buttered boiled potatoes or mash.
Preheat the oven to 200C/fan180C/gas 6.
Line one 18cm flan tin for every 2 people with the pastry, prick the base all over with a fork, then line the pastry with baking paper and fill with baking beans.
Blind bake for 15 minutes, remove the beans and baking paper, then blind bake for 5 minutes more.

Melt a knob of butter in a frying pan, add the leeks and cook over a medium heat for 10 minutes until soft. Cook the kale in boiling salted water for 4 to 5 minutes, drain well and squeeze dry. Add the kale to the pastry case with the leeks.
Whisk the eggs, cream, chives and Gruyère together, season well, then pour on top of the leeks and kale. Return to the oven and bake for 15-20 minutes until golden and set.
Serve with buttered baked potatoes.
Preheat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6
Melt the butter in a large pan over a medium-low heat, then add the leeks and thyme leaves. Season and fry gently, covered, for 10-15 minutes until softened. Remove from the heat.

Put the potatoes in a large pan of cold salted water and bring to the boil. Parboil for 10 minutes, drain, then add to the leek mix and gently stir through. Leave to cool completely, then mix through the vegetarian Stilton and walnuts. Season.
On a lightly floured surface, roll one half out to the thickness of a £1 coin, then use to line a loose-bottomed tart tin – it should just drape over the sides. Tip in the cooled filling.

Roll out the rest of the pastry, cut into thin strips, then lay them over the filling in a criss-cross. Trim the overhanging pastry with a sharp knife, then brush the lattice well with the beaten egg.
Place on a baking sheet and bake for 25 minutes until golden. Serve hot or cold.
Serve with buttered, bake potatoes.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Cook the macaroni in salted boiling water, uncovered, for 8 to 10 minutes. Drain well.
Stir two thirds of the cheese into the white sauce and season with salt and pepper.
Add the macaroni and tomatoes to the sauce. Transfer to a buttered, oven-proof dish.
Mix the remaining cheese with breadcrumbs and spoon over the macaroni. Trickle the melted butter over.
Bake near the top of the oven for 20 to 30 minutes until crisp and golden.
Serve with a winter salad or green vegetable.
Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Finely chop the chard stems and roughly chop the leaves. Put the stems in a colander and pour over a kettleful of boiling water. Drain, then mix in the leaves and set aside.
Melt the butter in a frying pan over a medium heat, then add the onion. Cook, stirring, for 5 to 6 minutes until softened, then add the garlic and cook for another 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer to a bowl.
Add an extra knob of butter to the pan and turn up the heat, then add the mushrooms with some salt. Fry over a high heat for 5 to 6 minutes, turning only once, until coloured and softened.
Return the onion mixture to the pan and reduce the heat. Add the chard and pour in the cream, then stir in the parsley. Bring to a bubble, season, then transfer to an oven-proof dish
Make an indentation for each egg in the mixture and crack an egg into each one, gently pushing the yolks down with the back of a spoon so they are covered by white. Sprinkle the cheese on top.
To keep the eggs runny, cover each one with a small tent of oiled foil. Bake for 20-25 minutes until the eggs are set.
Serve immediately with a squeeze of lemon juice and crusty bread.
Serve with crusty French bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7. Line a loaf tin with baking paper so that it overhangs the sides.
In a large frying pan, melt half of the butter and a little oil until the butter begins to foam. Add the onions and leeks, then fry for 10 to 15 minutes until softened and starting to caramelise.
Add the garlic and cook for 1 minute, then remove with a slotted spoon and set aside on a plate.
Melt the rest of the butter in the pan and add a little more oil, then turn up to a medium-high heat and fry the mushrooms until softened and golden.

Return the onion and leek mixture to the pan, pour in the sherry and bubble for a minute, then stir in the tarragon and plenty of seasoning. Set aside to cool completely. Stir in the cheese and mustard once cool.
Boil the eggs for 4 to 5 minutes , then remove with a slotted spoon and put in a bowl of iced water. Once cool, peel and set aside.

Layer filo sheets lengthways in the prepared loaf tin so they overhang the ends, reserving sufficient for the lid. Brush with oil as you work, then layer more filo sheets widthways, also leaving a large overhang on both sides of the tin.
Continue to brush each sheet carefully with oil as you work.
Once the tin is completely lined, spoon in half the mushroom filling. Make sufficient shallow indentations in the mixture with the back of a tablespoon and put a boiled egg in each one.
Cover with the rest of the mushroom mixture, then fold over the overhanging filo pastry. Roughly scrunch up the reserved filo and use it to top the pie.

Brush again with oil, then bake the pie for 30 minutes until the pastry is golden and crisp. Leave the pie to cool in the tin for 5 minutes, then use the overhanging strips of baking paper to lift the pie out.
Serve with sauté potatoes.

Melt half the butter in a large heavy-based frying pan over a medium-high heat. Once sizzling, fry the mushrooms for 8 to 10 minutes until softened and golden, adding a splash of oil if needed. Transfer to a plate.
Melt the remaining butter in the pan and add the onion. Cook for 6 to 8 minutes until softening, then stir in the garlic and half the thyme and cook for 1 minute.
Add the spelt and cook for 2 minutes, then pour in the stock, stir and bring to a simmer. Cook for 20 to 25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the spelt is tender but still has a little bite.

Stir in the spinach, two thirds of the pesto, the crème fraîche and the remaining thyme. Cook for another minute or so until the spinach has wilted, then serve with the remaining pesto drizzled over the top
Melt the butter in a pan. Fry the pine nuts with the garlic until lightly browned.
Add the onion, bay leaf and thyme and cook for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the mushrooms, turning gently, and cook for 20 minutes until the cooking juices have evaporated.
Roughly chop the tomatoes and add these and the olives to the mushrooms. Season. Stir and cook just until the tomatoes are hot.
Stir in the parsley.
Fill the pancakes with the mushroom/tomatoes mixture, rolling each one neatly.
Place in a flameproof dish. Pour over the hot Bechamel sauce.
Mix the breadcrumbs and cheese and sprinkle over. Place under a hot grill until the sauce is bubbling and the top is crisp and browned.
Cook the pasta according to the packet instructions.
Toast the pine nuts in a small pan (with no oil) and set aside.
Heat the olive oil in a pan and sauté the mushrooms and onions for about 5 minutes until lightly browned.
Add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds longer.
Deglaze the pan with the plant-based milk, reduce the heat and cook for another couple of minutes.
Add the spinach and cook until wilted (2 to 3 minutes).
Season, and combine with the pasta.
Add nutritional yeast or vegan Parmesan as desired.
Serve topped with the toasted pine nuts.
Turn the grill to medium-high. Boil the potatoes in a pan of salted water for 10 minutes or until just tender.
Heat a little oil in an oven-proof frying pan over a medium heat. Add the onion and fry for 5 to 8 minutes until softened. Add the chilli and most of the rosemary, then season with salt and pepper.
Fry for a couple of minutes more, then add the green beans and cook for a minute. Drain the potatoes well, add them to the pan and turn the heat to low.
Pour the beaten egg into the pan, then shake and tip the pan a little to make sure the egg coats everything evenly. Tear the mozzarella ball into pieces and scatter on top.

Fry the frittata for about 5 minutes on a medium heat to set the egg at the bottom of the pan. Put the pan under the hot grill and cook for 4 to 5 minutes until the frittata is just set. Serve when the eggs have just set.
Serve with a tomato salad.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Add the parsnips to a pan and add sufficient water to cover. Add salt and bring to the boil. Reduce the heat, cover the pan and boil for 5 minutes. Drain.
Heat half the oil in a large saucepan. Add the bay leaf, leek, celery and onion. Stir for 2 minutes, then cover and cook for 20 minutes, shaking the pan occasionally.
Stir in the flour and cook gently for 2 minutes, stirring. Gradually stir in the cider and bring to the boil, stirring continuously.
Gradually stir in the milk and bring back to the boil.
Add the parsnips and season. Add the parsley and Parmesan. Remove from the heat and stand for 5 minutes.
Heat the remaining oil with the butter in a small pan
Brush a little of butter/oil mixture onto a flan dish or tin.
Use two thirds of the pastry to line the dish, leaving the edges overhanging the edge. Brush each sheet with the butter mixture.
Cut the tofu into 2.5cm cubes and sprinkle over the pastry.
Remove the bay leaf from the parsnip mixture and spoon over and around the tofu.
Lay one of the remaining pastry sheets over the filling and brush it lightly with the butter mixture.
Fold over the overhanging pastry brushing with the butter mixture.
Lay the remaining sheet of pasty on top, pinching it together to form creases and folds. Brush with the remaining butter mixture.
Bake for 30 minutes. Then cover loosely with foil to prevent over-browning for a further 20 minutes.
Serve with spinach or cabbage and baked potatoes topped with soured cream

Put a large pan of salted water on to boil. Put the garlic in a blender or mini food processor with the Greek yogurt, the oil, lemon zest and salt and pepper, then process until smooth. Transfer to a large mixing bowl.
Once the water is boiling, add the pasta and cook according to the pack instructions. Add the asparagus and peas and broad beans to the pasta pan minutes before the end of the cooking time.
Spoon out a mugful of pasta water and keep to hand, then drain the pasta and veg in a colander. Leave to cool for a couple of minutes, then add to the bowl with the yogurt.

Toss everything well, slowly stirring in a little of the pasta water to loosen the mixture. As the pasta cools it will absorb the dressing. Keep stirring and adding more water every few minutes until the water is all used up and the pasta has cooled.
Once completely cool, tear in the baby spinach and basil leaves then squeeze in a little lemon juice to taste. Drizzle in a splash olive oil, then toss everything together well.
Check the seasoning. Crumble over the feta just before serving and sprinkle with sumac.
Serve with crusty bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 160C/140C fan/gas 3.
Peel the parsnips and slice thinly. Lightly fry in the oil for 4 or 5 minutes.
Skin and deseed the tomatoes and slice.
Grease an oven-proof casserole dish with half the butter.
Add a single layer of parsnips and season with a little sugar, salt and pepper. Add a little of the cream and cover with a layer of tomatoes. Add a little more cream and cheese.
Repeat the layers until all these ingredients are used, finishing with cream and cheese.
Top with the breadcrumbs and dot with the remaining butter.
Cook for 40 minutes in the centre of the oven.
Serve with roast lamb or pork, or on its own with winter greens.
Cook the peas in boiling water for 2 to 3 minutes, drain and refresh under cold water.
Cook the pasta in boiling salted water for 10 to 12 minutes until al dente. Drain, reserving a little cooking water. Return to the pan along with the water.
Meanwhile, in a food processor, process two-thirds of the peas with the rocket, mint, garlic, almonds and Parmesan. Season, then gradually add the oil, processing to a thick pesto.
Add the crème fraîche and a little of the reserved cooking water to loosen.
Stir the pesto through the hot pasta. Add the remaining peas and the pea shoots. Season, then divide among bowls and serve with extra Parmesan.
Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.
Put the dried Porcini mushrooms in a heatproof bowl, just cover with freshly boiled water, then set aside for 10 minutes to rehydrate.
Put the breadcrumbs in a separate bowl and strain over the liquid from the soaked mushrooms. Roughly chop the soaked mushrooms and set aside.

Heat a splash of oil in a large saucepan or casserole and gently fry the onion, carrot, celery, parsnip and thyme for 10 to 12 minutes until softened. Add the soaked and fresh mushrooms and the garlic, then cook for a further 5 minutes to soften.
Remove the pan from the heat, then stir in the soaked breadcrumbs and the remaining ingredients with some salt and pepper until mixed.
Grease a loaf tin and line with baking paper. Spoon the mixture into the tin and squash down to make sure it’s tightly packed, then cover with a piece of foil.

Bake for 45 minutes, remove the foil, then return to the oven for 10 to 15 minutes until browned and a knife pushed into the centre comes out clean. Leave in the tin for 5 to 10 minutes, then turn out onto a serving plate and scatter with fresh thyme.
Melt the butter in a large heavy-based pan over a medium heat. Whisk in the flour for 1 to 2 minutes, then gradually add the milk, whisking well between additions.
Simmer for 5 minutes, whisking frequently, to make a thick sauce. Stir in the cheeses until melted, then season to taste. Serve alongside the nut roast.
Serve with roast potatoes, seasonal green vegetables and the cheese sauce.
Tip the water into a pan and turn on the heat to medium. Add the ginger, garlic and mustard seed and stir. Bring to the boil and simmer until the ingredients are soft.
Add the tomatoes and cook them until they soften - 4 to 5 minutes.
Add the mushrooms, the paprika, some black pepper and stir to combine. Cook for another 5 minutes, stir frequently.
Add the potatoes and stir.
Add the tomato sauce or passata, a little more water if necessary, and stir again to combine. Bring to the boil, cover the pan with a lid, lower the heat to the minimum and cook for 15 minutes.
Add the peas, and increase the heat to medium. Simmer for another 10 minutes until the potatoes have cooked.
Serve with crusty bread.

Put the eggs in a pan, cover with boiling water, bring straight back to the boil and cook for 6 minutes for soft-boiled. Drain and run under cold water for a minute or so to stop them cooking further. Peel the eggs, leaving them whole, and set aside.

Heat the oil in a frying pan over a medium heat. Add the breadcrumbs, rosemary and seasoning, then cook, stirring often, for 5 to 6 minutes until the breadcrumbs are golden. Remove from the pan and set aside.
Trim the purple sprouting broccoli and halve or quarter any thick stems. Put in a large saucepan, cover with boiling water and simmer for 4 to 5 minutes until tender.
Drain and divide among plates. Slice each egg in half lengthways and put 2 halves on each plate.
Scatter with the rosemary breadcrumbs, drizzle with a little more olive oil and squeeze over a little lemon juice, with some salt and pepper and chilli flakes.
Heat the oil in a large pan and add the sweet potato. Cook for 30 seconds.
Add the spices and stir to combine.
Add a small amount of water and cover the pan.
Reduce heat to low and cook for about 6 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add the baby spinach, stir and cook for another 2 minutes.
Stir in the beans, and cherry tomatoes and heat through. Season.
Divide the mixture between the tortillas, covering just half of each tortilla and leaving a half inch border.
Sprinkle grated cheese over the mixture.
Heat oil in a frying pan, over a medium-low heat.
Fold over each tortilla to form a semi-circle and fry for 2 to 3 minutes each side.
Cut each quesadilla into 2 or 3 wedges and serve.

Put the whole sweet potatoes in a large pan of salted boiling water and cook for about 20 minutes until tender but still firm. Drain, slice into 1cm discs and put in a bowl a little of the olive oil and two thirds of the za’atar. Turn gently to coat.

Put a griddle pan over a high heat until smoking. Brush the spring onions with olive oil, then griddle for 1-2 minutes on each side until soft and marked with char lines. Set aside in a large salad bowl.
Put the cooked sweet potato slices in the griddle pan and fry for 2-3 minutes on each side until char lines appear. Add the charred sweet potatoes to the bowl with the spring onions.

To make the dressing, mix the remaining olive oil with the garlic, cider vinegar and the remaining za’atar. Add the lamb’s lettuce, feta and toasted pumpkin seeds to the griddled veg, then toss together with the dressing.
Pre-heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 6
Toss the pumpkin and leek in a large roasting tin with half the olive oil and a pinch each of salt and black pepper. Roast for 30 minutes.

Toss the mushrooms with the remaining olive oil, a few sage leaves and a handful of walnuts. Add to the tin, crumble over the Stilton and roast for 10 minutes more until charred and the cheese has melted.
Serve with crusty bread and a side salad.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Put the celeriac, shallots, mushrooms and half of the thyme leaves in a large roasting tin, drizzle with half of the oil and sprinkle with salt and pepper.
Roast for 25 minutes, turning the vegetables halfway through, until tender and starting to caramelise.
Drizzle the remaining oil into a baking dish, then warm in the oven for 5 minutes.
Make a batter by sifting the flour and baking powder into a large mixing bowl, then make a well in the centre. Crack in the eggs, then pour in the milk.
Using a balloon whisk, beat to make a smooth batter. Whisk in the horseradish, remaining thyme leaves and some salt and pepper.
Sprinkle the kale into the warm oil in the baking dish, then pour in the batter and arrange the roasted veg on top. Bake for 25-30 minutes until puffed up, golden and cooked through.

Roughly chop the remaining thyme sprigs, along with the leaves from the rosemary sprigs and the sage leaves. Mix with the salt. Sprinkle over the pudding to serve, along with a jug of hot gravy, some mustard, and extra horseradish sauce.
Make a tomato sauce by putting the extra oil and half the garlic in a medium pan set over a medium-high heat.
As soon as the garlic is sizzling, add the tomatoes, stir and leave to simmer until thickened slightly to a good sauce consistency (30 to 40 minutes). Season and keep warm.
Make garlic and dill yogurt by mixing the rest of the garlic, dill leaves and yoghurt in a small bowl, taste and add salt. Cover and chill until needed.

For the fritters, heat the oven to 150C/130C fan/gas 2. Boil a pan of water and cook the greens for 3 to 4 minutes until tender. Drain, refresh under cold water, then press out the excess water. Tip onto a board and coarsely chop.
Half-fill a deep saucepan with oil and heat until the temperature reads 180°C on a digital probe thermometer or until a cube of bread turns golden 60 seconds after being added to the pan.
Sift the flour, baking powder, nutmeg and salt into a mixing bowl. Add the eggs and whisk together to form a smooth batter. Stir in the ricotta, Parmesan and cooked greens.
Using 2 dessertspoons, shape the mixture into egg shapes and drop carefully into the hot oil. Make 6 to 7 fritters at a time.
Fry for 3 minutes, flipping them halfway through, until puffed up, golden brown (they will go darker at the edges) and cooked through.
Using a slotted spoon, lift onto a baking tray lined with lots of kitchen paper and keep hot in the oven while you cook the rest. Serve hot with the tomato sauce and garlic and dill yogurt.
Put all the ingredients, apart from the spaghetti, into a small food processor with a little water, then process to a fine paste. Season, then pulse to mix in.
Bring a large pan of salted water to the boil, then cook the spaghetti according to the pack instructions until al dente (firm to the bite). Drain, reserving a little of the cooking water.
Add the sauce to the pasta with a splash of cooking water and mix well. Serve scattered with the reserved parsley, extra cheese and a final drizzle of olive oil.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6.

Heat the oil in a medium pan, then fry the onion for 6 to 8 minutes until softened. Add the garlic and fry for a minute, then add the red wine. Turn up the heat and bubble for 3 to 4 minutes to reduce by half.
Add the tomatoes, sugar, Worcester sauce and tomato purée. Reduce the heat and simmer for 15 to 20 minutes until thickened. Add the basil and season.
Put the spinach in a large pan with a knob of butter. Cover and cook over a medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes until the spinach has wilted.
Drain in a colander, then squeeze out any excess water. Roughly chop, then mix with the butter, ricotta, mascarpone, egg yolks, lemon zest and a grating of nutmeg. Season.
Spread a little of the spinach and ricotta sauce over the base of the baking dish, then cover with lasagne sheets.
Pour over a third of the remaining spinach and ricotta sauce, sprinkle over a little of the grated cheese and top with half the tomato sauce.
Cover with another layer of lasagne sheets, top with half the remaining spinach and ricotta sauce, then all the remaining tomato sauce.
Add the final layer of lasagne sheets, then spread with the rest of the spinach and ricotta e sauce. Scatter with the remaining grated cheese.
Top with the mozzarella slices, then the Parmesan and bake for 30 minutes until golden and bubbling
Serve with green salad and crusty bread.
Pre-heat oven to 200C/fan180C/gas 4
Add oil to a pan and place on low heat. Add the onions and fry gently for around 10 minutes until soft and browning.
Add the garlic and fry for a further 30 seconds.
Add the peppers, courgettes and mushrooms and fry for another couple of minutes.
Add the tomatoes and lentils and cook on a low heat for 25 minutes, covered.
Make the bechamel sauce by melting the butter over a low heat and then adding the flour and combining.
Add the milk a small amount at a time, stirring constantly to avoid lumps.
Add the nutritional yeast and simmer for 5 minutes to thicken. Season well.
For the pesto, add the walnuts, pine nuts, spinach, basil, nutritional yeast, lemon juice and garlic cloves to a food processor and blitz until smooth.
In a roasting dish, layer as follows:
a third of the vegetable filling
lasagne sheets to cover
a third of the vegetable filling
lasagne sheets to cover
half the bechamel sauce
half the pesto
a third of the vegetable filling
lasagne sheets to cover
half the bechamel sauce
half the pesto
Finally, top with vegan cheese.
Cover and bake for 30 minutes.
Remove cover and bake for a further 5 to 10 minutes until cheese has melted.
Rinse the spinach and shake off the moisture. Put in a large pan, lightly salt, and cook for 5 minutes or until softened.
Squeeze out any moisture and liquidise to make a puree.
Melt a third of the butter in a pan and re-heat the spinach puree. Season with salt, pepper and nutmeg.
Spread over the base of a flame-proof dish.
Trim the mushrooms and place over the spinach - rounded side up. Place under a low grill for 5 minutes until the mushrooms are cooked and browned.
Use the remaining butter, the flour and milk to make a white sauce. Season and continue to cook, stirring continuously, until the sauce has thickened. Add the grated cheese and stir until melted.
Pour over the sauce and return to the grill. Turn up the heat and grill until brown and bubbling.
Serve with crusty bread.
Heat the oil in a large heavy-based saucepan. Add the onion and bay leaf and cook for 10 minutes.
Stir in the rice and lemon rind, stirring until the rice is well covered with oil. Season.
Pour in half the stock and bring to the boil. Cover the pan tightly and reduce to lowest setting. Cook for 5 minutes.
Add the remining stock, recover and cook at a gentle simmer for another 5 minutes.
Add little boiling water to the saffron threads and press with the back of a spoon.
Add the saffron and its liquid and the wine to the risotto. Stir well and bring back to simmering point. Add the asparagus, recover and cook for 5 minutes.
Stir the risotto and add the courgettes and peas. Recover and cook for 5 minutes.
Remove from the heat but do not remove the lid. Leave to stand for 10 minutes, then gently mix .
Sprinkle with grated vegan Parmesan and serve with crusty bread.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Remove the stalks from the mushrooms and place rounded sides down in 1 or 2 oven-proof dishes.
Chop the mushroom stalks. Peel and grate the onion and apple, add the walnuts and cheese. Add the breadcrumbs and season.
Add the milk and mix well.
Mould the stuffing neatly into the mushrooms.
Bake for 30 minutes until browned and the mushrooms are lightly cooked.
Serve on rounds of toast.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
For the pastry, mix the flour with the unsmoked sea salt, a good grinding of black pepper and a little of the thyme leaves in a food processor.

Add the butter and pulse until the mix starts to look like breadcrumbs. Add a little ice-cold water and pulse again until the mixture comes together to form a ball. Tip out onto a large sheet of cling film, wrap, then chill for 30 minutes.
On a lightly floured work surface, roll out the pastry the thickness of £1 coin and wide enough to fit a tart tin.

Lift up the pastry with the flour-dusted rolling pin, drape into the tart tin and gently press to line the edges. Trim any excess pastry, leaving a small overhang proud of the tin. Rest in the fridge for 15 minutes.
Prick the pastry base all over with a fork, line with a piece of scrunched baking paper or foil, then fill with baking beans.

Bake for 20 minutes until the edges feel firm, then remove the paper or foil and the beans and bake for 6 to 8 minutes more until the pastry is golden and sandy to the touch. Set aside on a wire rack to cool fully in the tin.

Beat together the Ricotta and Pecorino in a mixing bowl with a third of the olive oil, the honey, some of the remaining thyme, lemon zest, black pepper and a little smoked sea salt. Remove the pastry case from its tin and put on a serving plate.
Spoon in the ricotta mixture and level using the back of a spoon. Slice the tomatoes and arrange on top, starting with the larger ones, then layering the smaller ones on top.
Drizzle with the rest of the oil, then finish with salt and pepper and the extra thyme and basil leaves.
Serve with minted new potatoes.
Pre-heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4.

Put the pumpkin on a large baking tray with the thyme sprigs and sprinkle with the olive oil. Season generously with sea salt and ground black pepper, then roast in the oven for 40 minutes or until tender and caramelised at the edges.
Once cooked, keep warm.
Towards the end of the pumpkin cooking time, bring a large pan of water to the boil and season generously with salt. Once boiling, add the tortellini and cook until tender but still with some bite.
Drain and reserve a little of the starchy cooking water to use in the sauce.
Put a large heavy-based frying pan over a low-medium heat and add the butter. Add the hazelnuts to the pan, tossing to coat them evenly in the warm butter.
Cook for 4 to 5 minutes until the hazelnuts have toasted. Stir in the sage leaves and allow to toast in the golden butter mix.
Toss the roasted pumpkin and tortellini into the pan, adding a splash of reserved pasta cooking water to loosen, if needed.
Serve the pasta on warmed plates. Crumble over some blue cheese along with a drizzle of olive oil. Finish with a sprinkle of salt and a grinding of black pepper.
Serve with crusty bread.
Preheat oven to 200C/fan180C/gas 4
Cook the macaroni according to the packet instructions. Drain.
Melt the butter in a pan over a low heat, add the flour and stir to combine.
Add the milk and stock a bit at a time and stir constantly to avoid lumps.
Whisk mixture until it starts to boil, lower the heat to a simmer and continue to whisk while it thickens.
Remove from the heat and add all other ingredients except the breadcrumbs, whisk until incorporated and no lumps.
Add the drained macaroni and pour into baking dish. Top with the breadcrumbs.
Bake in the oven for 20 minutes until topping is golden brown and crispy.
Serve with a green salad.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6

Sift the flour into a large bowl with a pinch of salt. Make a well in the centre, crack in the eggs and whisk to combine. Add the milk and mix to make a smooth batter. Stir in the mustard, season well, then set the batter aside for up to 2 hours.

Toss the carrots and onions with the chilli, sumac and oil in a roasting tin. Roast for 15 minutes, then increase the heat to 220C/200C fan/gas 7 and pour the batter over. Bake for 20 minutes until golden brown and risen.
Cut the bake into wedges and serve with warmed gravy and baked potatoes.
Bring a large pan of water to the boil. In a mini food processor, process the garlic, mint, basil, Parmesan, oil and lemon juice. Season.
Heat a little oil in a medium frying pan over a high heat, add the ’nduja or the chorizo, then fry for 3 to 4 minutes, stirring, until it starts to melt and bubble.
Add the breadcrumbs to the pan and cook for a further 2 to 3 minutes until crispy, then turn off the heat.

Add the pasta to the boiling water and cook according to the packet instructions until just al dente. Drain, then return to the pan. To serve, stir the pesto into the pasta and scatter the crispy ‘ndjua breadcrumbs on top. Sprinkle with extra Parmesan.
Pre-heat the oven to 220C/200C fan/gas 7.
Put the potatoes in a saucepan of cold salted water and bring to the boil. Cook for 7 minutes, then drain and leave to steam dry.
Heat the oil in a large roasting tin for 2 minutes, add the chicken skin-side down, then roast for 5 minutes to crisp up.
Partly squash the potatoes with a masher to rough up the edges.
Grind the cumin seeds and garlic with the berbere in a pestle and mortar. In a small bowl, combine a third of the mixture with the maple syrup.
Turn down the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6. Turn the chicken over and add the remaining two thirds of the spice mix from the mortar to the tin.
Add the potatoes to the tin, toss everything together well, then roast for 25 minutes. Drizzle the maple syrup mix over the chicken and roast for 10 minutes more.
Put the spring greens in a colander and pour over a kettle of freshly boiled water to soften, then add to the roasting tin and cook for 3 minutes more.
Sprinkle the tray-roast with the spring onions, coriander, lime zest and a squeeze of the juice, then serve with lime wedges.
Preheat the oven to 200C/fan180C/gas 6.
For the fritters, put the chicken, garlic, pumpkin and herbs in a roasting tin. Season and drizzle with the oil. Toss together leaving the chicken thighs skin side up at the end.

Roast for 20 to 25 minutes until the chicken and pumpkin are almost cooked, then scatter the pepitas and cook for a further 10 minutes until golden. Remove from the oven and leave until cool enough to handle.
Remove the chicken skin, and discard. Slice the meat thinly and put in a bowl. Roughly mash half the pumpkin and roughly chop the rest.
Add to the bowl, along with any juices and browned bits from the roasting tin. Mix in the spring onion, parsley and egg, then scatter with the flour and mix in well. Chill in the fridge to firm up.
For the gratin, put the stock and cream in a small pan and bring to the boil, then turn down the heat to a rapid simmer and cook until reduced by one-third. Butter a ceramic roasting dish.
Slice all the vegetables to a thickness of 0.5cm. Put the sliced vegetables in a bowl and toss with the herbs, then layer them in the roasting dish, keeping the slices as flat as possible.
Add a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper to the cream mixture, as well as the sea salt. Pour over the vegetables and place a sheet of baking paper on top.
Place the gratin dish on a baking sheet (to protect the oven in case of overspill) and place in the centre of the oven.
Bake for 40 minutes, at which point you should be able to insert a thin knife into the vegetables. Remove the paper (but keep it) and bake the gratin until the top turns golden.

Remove the fritter mixture from the fridge. Dust your hands with flour and gently form the mixture into balls (4 or 5 per person), each about the size of a golf ball. If they’re soft, put them back in the fridge for 15 to 20 minutes to firm up.
Heat the groundnut oil, to a level of about 0.5cm, in a large, heavy-based frying pan over a medium-high heat.
Flatten the fritters slightly and fry in batches for 3 to 4 minutes on each side until golden. Keep on a dish in a warm oven while you cook the remaining fritters.

Take the gratin from the oven and gently press the paper back on top to even out the surface. To serve, scoop out the gratin with a spoon or cut slices and remove with a metal spatula. Serve with the fritters.
Put the chicken, soy sauce, mirin and sesame oil in a bowl and set aside to marinate.
For the broth, put the chilli, garlic, ginger and stock in a large saucepan. Simmer over a medium heat and cook for 15 minutes, then strain and return the liquid to the pan (discard the solids).
Add the carrots and mushrooms and cook for another 5 minutes until softened. Season to taste with salt and sesame oil.

Before the end of the cooking time, blanch the broccoli in the broth for 2 to 3 minutes until tender, then remove with a slotted spoon and set aside. While the broth simmers, cook the noodles according to the pack instructions, then drain and set aside.

To cook the chicken, heat a griddle pan or frying pan over a high heat. Remove the chicken from the marinade and cook for 4 minutes on each side or until cooked all the way through and the chicken has deep char marks. Remove from the heat and slice.

Arrange the noodles in bowls with the broccoli, chicken slices, beansprouts, spring onions and soft boiled eggs. Ladle over the hot broth with the carrots and mushrooms, then serve straightaway garnished with fresh coriander and mint.

Heat a griddle pan to high. In a small bowl, mix the oil, paprika, chipotle sauce and the finely grated zest and juice of half the limes. Transfer half to a separate bowl and mix with the mayonnaise to make a dressing.
When the griddle pan is hot, peel back the husks from the corn, cut off or tie back with string, then brush each cob with some chipotle and lime mixture.
Cook, turning and basting with the rest of the chipotle and lime mixture, until beginning to char on all sides (10 to 15 minutes).
Once cool enough to handle, hold each cob vertically on a secure chopping board and carefully slice down the sides with a sharp knife to remove the kernels.
