Warm the tortillas in the griddle pan for 1 or 2 minutes. Top with avocado, chicken, spring onions, tomatoes, charred corn, a spoonful of dressing and a few coriander leaves. Serve with the remaining limes, cut into wedges, for squeezing.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C /180 fan/gas 6.
Wrap each leek section in a piece of chicken. Arrange in the base of an oven-proof dish.
Meanwhile, melt the butter in a pan, then stir in the flour and cook over a medium heat for 2 to 3 minutes. Gradually whisk in the wine and milk. Bring to the boil, then simmer for 3 minutes.

Stir in the wholegrain mustard, thyme leaves and Cheddar until melted, then pour over the leeks. Top with the Brie, then bake for 30 minutes until bubbling. Scatter with more thyme and serve with crusty bread.
Heat the spray oil in a non-stick frying pan, add the chicken breasts and fry for about 10 minutes, or until well browned on both sides. Set aside.

In the same pan, add a little more oil and fry the onion for 2 to 3 minutes, or until translucent. Add the garlic and fry for another 1 to 2 minutes. Add the mushrooms and fry until golden-brown. If they start to stick, add a little stock to the pan.

Return the chicken to the pan and stir in the stock. Bring to the boil. Cover with a tight fitting lid, lower the heat and simmer for 12 to 15 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through. Season with salt and pepper.
Cook the broccoli in boiling salted water until tender.
Stir the crème fraîche and parsley into the sauce and serve immediately with the broccoli.

Put the flour and a pinch of salt into a food processor with the margarine and process until it resembles fine breadcrumbs, then add enough cold water to bind the ingredients. Remove from the processor and press together gently, wrap and chill.
Melt the butter in a saucepan and add the onions and bay leaf, cook gently for 5 minutes.
Stir in the chicken and bacon and cook for a further 5 minutes. Add the red pepper, mushrooms and oregano and cook for another 3 minutes.

Stir in the flour and cook for 1 minute, then add the wine. Gradually add the water and milk, stirring continuously until the sauce comes to the boil. Reduce the heat and simmer gently for 5 minutes. Season and remove the bay leaf.
Pour into a pie dish and allow to cool before covering with pastry.
Roll out the pastry on a floured surface so that it is 5cm larger than the dish. Trim a 2.5cm strip from the pastry, dampen the edge of pie dish and press the strip around the edge.
Dampen the pastry strip and cover with the pastry, pressing to seal. Trim the pie and crimp the edges. Make a small hole in the top. Re-roll the trimmings and use to decorate the pie.
Brush with milk and bake for 35 to 40 minutes.
Serve with glazed carrots and mashed potato.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/ gas 6
Heat a little oil in a heavy- based frying pan over a high heat, and cook the chicken, skin-side down, for 3 to 5 minutes until golden.
Set the pan aside. Put the chicken in a baking dish skin-side-up and roast for 20 to 25 minutes until the pieces are cooked through. Rest the supremes for 5 minutes.
Add the butter to the reserved pan and put on the lowest heat. Add the shallots and garlic, then cook for around 7 minutes.
Add the chicken stock and white wine, turn up the heat then reduce over a high heat for 15 to 20 minutes. Add the cream and bubble to reduce for about 3 minutes more.
Heat another knob of butter and a little oil in a frying pan over a high heat. When foaming, add the mushrooms and cook for 5 to 8 minutes, tossing occasionally, until dark golden.
Add the mushrooms to the sauce with the tarragon, mustard and a squeeze of lemon juice, then taste and season.
Pour in any resting juices from the chicken, then serve with the chicken supremes, either spooned over on plates or served at the table on a large platter.
Serve with roast potatoes and broccoli stems.
Slice the broccoli stalks and break the heads into florets.
Blanch the broccoli in boiling, salted water for 2 minutes. Drain well.
Cut the chicken crossways into thin slices. Place in a bowl, season well, add the flour and a little nutmeg and toss until well coated.
Heat the oil in a large frying pan or wok. Add the bay leaf and onion and stir fry for 3 minutes.
Add the chicken (retaining any flour left in the bowl). Continue to stir fry for about 8 minutes until the chicken is cooked and browned.
Add the almonds and broccoli and stir fry for a further 3 minutes.

Stir in any remaining flour. Add the sherry and water. Reduce the heat slightly and bring slowly to the boil, stirring continuously until slightly thickened and smooth. Lower the heat and simmer gently for 3 minutes.
Remove the bay leaf and season.
Serve with rice, pasta or baked potatoes.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6.
Flatten the chicken breasts slightly by pressing with a rolling pin between 2 sheets of cling film.Heat the oil in a large frying pan over a medium heat.

Season the chicken breasts and sear, skin-side down, for 2 minutes, then turn and briefly sear the other side. Transfer to a roasting tin and cook in the oven for 12 to 15 minutes until the juices run clear when pierced with a knife.
Put the pancetta in the pan and fry until crisp. Add the pumpkin or squash and the hot chicken stock and cook for 5 to 6 minutes until tender.
Add the chopped sage and the chickpeas, stir, then cook for a few minutes more. Serve topped with the sliced chicken, scattered with the parsley.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Cut the chicken breasts horizontally in half to create thinner fillets. Put in a deep, wide frying or sauté pan with the shallots and garlic, then cover with the milk.
Over a medium heat, bring up to a simmer, then turn the heat down to its lowest heat so the milk is barely bubbling. Season and poach for 15 minutes or until the chicken is cooked through.
Once the chicken is cooked, transfer to a board and use 2 forks to shred into chunks. In a small bowl, mix the butter into the flour.
Skim any scum off the surface of the poaching milk, then bring back to a simmer. Add the butter and flour mixture a little at a time, whisking, until the milk has thickened. Season.

Stir the chicken, artichokes, spinach, herbs and white wine into the sauce. Spoon into a pie dish and top with scrunched up filo sheets. Brush the filo with olive oil, then bake for 35 to 40 minutes until golden and bubbling.
Serve with new potatoes and green beans.
Lay cling film over a chopping board, put the chicken breast on top, then cover the chicken with another sheet of cling film.
Using a rolling pin, bash the chicken to flatten it to an even thickness. Season with salt and pepper, the rosemary and half the lemon zest.

Heat half the butter and two thirds of the oil in a small non-stick frying pan, then cook the chicken for 10 to 12 minutes, turning, until golden, adding the remaining butter to the pan as you turn. Continue to cook until the chicken is cooked through.
For the salsa verde, mix the remaining oil and lemon zest, a little lemon juice, the shallot, garlic, soft herbs and capers in a small bowl. Season.
Transfer the cooked chicken to a warm serving plate to rest. Add a good splash of white wine to the frying pan and stir over the heat to release any bits stuck to the bottom.
Halve or slice the chicken, then toss in the warm pan juices. Serve drizzled with the salsa verde, new potatoes and salad.
Brown the chicken in batches over a low heat and transfer to a slow cooker.
Fry the onions until just softened (about 5 minutes) and then add the garlic and paprika, before cooking for another minutes. Add to the slow cooker.
Swirl the water around pan and pour into slow cooker as well.
Add the remaining ingredients to the slow cooker, and cook for 6 to 8 hours on low, until the chicken is tender.
Shred the chicken using two forks.
Serve in burger buns with French fries.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6.
Heat a sauté pan over a medium-high heat, then cook the chicken breasts, skin-side down, for 4 to 5 minutes. Season, then turn the chicken and cook for another minute.
Transfer to a roasting tin (set aside the pan with the fat) and roast for 20 minutes or until the chicken is cooked.
Boil the potatoes, chopped if large, for 15 minutes or until tender. Add the broad beans for the last 3 minutes. Drain.
Put the sauté pan back on a medium heat. When hot, fry the garlic cloves for 2 minutes, then add the chicken stock. Simmer for 5 minutes, then add the potatoes and beans.
Stir in the lemon juice, some mascarpone and fresh herbs. Season the chicken, then slice and serve on top of the vegetables.
Pre-heat the oven to 200C/180C fan/gas 6
Put the chicken breasts, butternut squash wedges and two thirds of the garlic cloves in a roasting tin, season with salt and pepper and drizzle with a little olive oil.

Pour over a splash of white wine and roast for 25 to 30 minutes until the chicken is cooked (the juices will run clear when the flesh is pierced in the thickest part with a skewer) and the squash is tender.
Peel the remaining garlic clove and put in the small bowl of a food processor (or a pestle and mortar) with the nuts, herbs, lemon zest and juice, Pecorino and olive oil.
Process or grind to a rough paste, then season. Add a drop of water if the pesto is too thick to drizzle.
For the last 5 minutes of the cooking time add the bread to the tray of chicken, drizzle with oil and cook until the bread is crisp and browned. Drizzle over the pesto and serve.
Serve with buttered rice or pasta.
Heat the oil in a large frying pan, add the chorizo and fry for 3 to 4 minutes until turning crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon, leaving the flavoured oil in the pan.
Add the onion and garlic and cook gently for 8 minutes or until soft, then add the tomatoes and stock. Turn up the heat to high and bubble to reduce for 10 minutes.

Add the chicken and chickpeas with the chorizo and any resting juices, then cook for 3 to 5 minutes until warmed though. Season with salt, pepper and the lemon juice, then scatter with the chopped parsley and serve.
